Authoring, writing and publishing with
R Markdown - part 2

Thomas Huet, University of Oxford

Code chunks

R code chunks are placeholders for the coding part of the document, expressed with a local header, and a body part.

Headers

  • Headers options
  • Options hierarchy

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}

Options are used to show/hide the code, change the size of the output image, set the alignment of the ouptut, etc.

https://github.com/zoometh/thomashuet/blob/main/teachings/stats/R4Archaeo/temp.pdf

code chunk

{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

The top chunk of the .Rmd file is commonly used to set global options for all subsequent chunks, unless you override these options locally within the headers of individual code chunks.

Tools

code chunks tools


tool description
graphical interface for options
run the previous chunks but not this one
run this chunk

Code evaluation

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}


code description
include = FALSE prevents code and results from appearing in the rendered file. R Markdown still runs the code in the chunk, and the results can be used by other chunks.
echo = FALSE prevents code, but not the results from appearing in the rendered file.
message = FALSE prevents messages that are generated by code from appearing in the rendered file.
warning = FALSE prevents warnings that are generated by code from appearing in the rendered file.


Graphical options

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, fig.height = 10, fig.with = 10}


code description
fig.cap = "..." adds a caption to graphical results.
fig.height = 7 height for plots created by the chunk (in inches).
fig.width = 7 width for plots created by the chunk (in inches).
fig.align = default how to align graphics in the final document. One of 'left', 'right', or 'center'.
fig.pos = 'H' fix the output exactly here.


Body

The body of a code chunk is where you place the R code

code chunk

{r munsingenspat, echo=TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}
library(dplyr)
library(leaflet)
munsingen.long <- 7.569587484129203
munsingen.lat <- 46.864709895956004
leaflet(width = "60%", height = "400px") %>%
  addTiles(group = 'OSM') %>%
  addControl("Munsingen necropolis", position = "bottomright") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.WorldImagery, group='Esri.WorldImagery') %>%
  addMarkers(munsingen.long,
             munsingen.lat,
             label = "Munsingen necropolis") %>%
  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c('OSM', 'Esri.WorldImagery')) %>%
  addScaleBar(position = "bottomleft")

Images

Images can be render inside a code chunk:

code chunk

knitr::include_graphics("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/thomashuet/master/teach/www/munsingen_fib_measures.png")


YAML

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: '2023-02-05'
---

This is the document header, it contains the metadata (e.g, title), the document output format (e.g, PDF) and configuration (e.g. table of content). It is composed on key - value pairs:


YAML dates

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: "'r format(Sys.time(), '%D')'"
---

01/31/24

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: "'r format(Sys.time(), '%d %B %Y')'"
---

31 January 2024

Warning

Here the ` quote has been changed to a â€™ quote for display purpose


YAML output

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  pdf_document
---

YAML table of content

Table of content (TOC)

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  html_document:
    toc: true
    toc_depth: 2
    toc_float:
      collapsed: false
      smooth_scroll: false
---

YAML references

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: "31 January 2024"
bibliography: references.bib
---

Reference the bibliographic file (e.g. references.bib). Here in the same folder as the .Rmd file.

see Xie et al. (2018)


Styling

  • HTML/CSS
  • In the document
  • In a CSS file

/ can be use in all parts of the document

code chunk

...
water.values <- paste0("<b>", Oxford.water$Place, "</b><br>", 
                       "Observed: ", Oxford.water$OxfordPct)
water.residuals <- paste0("<b>", Oxford.water$Place, "</b><br>",
                          "Observed: ", round(Oxford.water$predicted, 2))
...
          add_trace(name = "Regression line", x = ~OxfordDst, y = fitted(lm.water),
                    mode = 'lines', line = list(color = 'darkgrey', width = 1.5),
                    text = ~paste0("R<sup>2</sup>: ", round(r2.water, 2)),
                    hoverinfo = 'text') %>%
...
        layout(title = paste0('Oxford pottery with a probable <b>no water</b> ', 
                              'transportation <br> (R<sup>2</sup> = ', r2.nowater, ")"),
...


narrative part

<span style='font-size: 60px'>Big font</span>

Big font

narrative part

<b>bolded</b>

bolded

narrative part

<span style="color:red">red</span>

red


Use a CSS file to customize styles

https://github.com/zoometh/thomashuet/blob/main/teachings/stats/r4a/styles.css

This file is called inside the YAML header of the document:

header YAML

---
title: "Report with R Markdown"
subtitle: "Report data analysis with R Markdown authoring framework"
author: "Thomas Huet, University of Oxford"
format:
  revealjs: 
    slide-number: true
    chalkboard: true
    scrollable: true
    logo: www/inst-uni-oxford_.png
    css: styles.css
    margin: 0.01
bibliography: references.bib
pagetitle: Report with R Markdown
---

Here in the same folder as the .Rmd file. Do:

narrative part

Customize with CSS like this <notes>**dodgerblue** background</notes>.

Customize with CSS like this dodgerblue background.

Interactivity

  • Shiny
  • Leaflet
  • Plotly

Shiny offers a framework to create interactive documents

header YAML

runtime: shiny

Note

Try: File > New File > Rmarkdown > Shiny, or in the YAML header. There are different ways to use Shiny in R Markdown, for example by embedding an HTML widget created by Shiny outside the R Markdown document, or by embedding the Shiny coding directly.


Maps with the package

code chunk

library(dplyr)
library(leaflet)
munsingen.long <- 7.569587484129203
munsingen.lat <- 46.864709895956004
leaflet(width = "90%", height = "300px") %>%
  addTiles(group = 'OSM') %>%
  addControl("Munsingen necropolis", position = "bottomright") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.WorldImagery, group='Esri.WorldImagery') %>%
  addMarkers(munsingen.long,
             munsingen.lat,
             label = "Munsingen necropolis") %>%
  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c('OSM', 'Esri.WorldImagery')) %>%
  addScaleBar(position = "bottomleft")


2D plots with the package

code chunk

library(plotly)
library(dplyr)
library(archdata)
data("Fibulae")
Fibulae.ex <- Fibulae
Fibulae.ex$lbl <- paste0("<b>Museum num.: ", Fibulae.ex$Mno, "</b><br>",
                          "Length: ", Fibulae.ex$Length, "<br>",
                          "Foot Angle: ", Fibulae.ex$FA, "<br>")
plot_ly(data = Fibulae.ex, 
        x = ~Length,
        y = ~FA,
        text = ~lbl,
        hoverinfo = "text")


Export document

Export R Markdown in: , , , , , , HTML, PDF, LaTeX, Word, ODT, RTF, Markdown, etc.

HTML

HTML export is the default option of a R Markdown document.

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output: html_document
---

PDF

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output: pdf_document
---

Note

For advanced editing, read below

is useful in R Markdown for chunk calls, and more generally for cross-referencing. PDF uses LaTeX syntax, if you donâ€™t have MiKTeX installed, you need to install the package (Xie 2019).

install.packages('tinytex')
tinytex::install_tinytex()
# .rs.restartR()

To export in PDF, use bookdown::pdf_document2: and knit.

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  bookdown::pdf_document2:
    css: styles.css
    toc: yes
    toc_depth: 4
    toc_float:
      collapsed: no
bibliography: references.bib
---

These temporary files are creates:

At the end of the rendering, these files are deleted.

LaTeX

LaTeX (extension of TeX) is a rich plain text syntax for academic writing. To export in TeX, select in the YAML header a PDF export + keep tex:

header YAML

---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  bookdown::pdf_document2: 
    keep_tex: true
---

Publishing

  • On Rpubs
  • On GitHub and GitLab

On , after Render:

https://rpubs.com/

On GitHub , or GitLab , the same document, or related documents, are accessibles by different means:

output URL
raw https://raw.githubusercontent.com/zoometh/thomashuet/main/teachings/stats/R4Archaeo/practice/2_Rmarkdown_Practice.Rmd

PDF https://github.com/zoometh/thomashuet/blob/main/teachings/stats/R4Archaeo/practice/2_Rmarkdown_Practice.pdf
